content:
Hello everyone. Nice to see this is such a big and active group.

I'm an engineer (nano, chemical engineering, surface physics) by trade, but I do math and programming as a hobby. I am very new to formal proofs however, and am looking forward to learning that while at the same time learning Lean. The last few years, I have been working on the Collatz conjecture (because it is honestly very fun and educational) and I finally got to the point where my requirements were exceeding my memory limits. So I looked into getting GMP for working with very large integers, and to my pleasant surprise I saw that it is implemented within lean. And here I am.

I am curious how well Lean is suited to data manipulation and visualization. I currently use IgorPro by Wavemetrics to crunch numbers and investigate the many patterns within the Collatz tree. But that only gets me so far before I hit floating point errors... As it stands, I can barely understand what the type logic is doing when looking at Lean code, so I will definitely be doing a lot of tutorials the next few weeks.

Hi! Some papers to read:

Buzzard, K.: What is the point of computers? A question for pure mathematicians, Proc. Int. Cong. Math. 2022, Vol. 2, pp. 578–608. https://doi.org/10.4171/icm2022/166

Kontorovich, A.: Foreword to: Special Issue on Interactive Theorem Provers, Experimental Mathematics, Volume 31, Issue 2 (2022). https://doi.org/10.1080/10586458.2022.2088982

Thank you, Yagub. I wonder what Buzzard thinks now with the rapid advance of machine learning, regarding his 2021 remarks about what we should expect from computers, and what they would be incapable of.
:astonished: haha thats great! might just do that when im done reading it all.

Welcome, Ian, from a fellow chemical engineer! You may enjoy our recent paper on using Lean in chemistry applications, while introducing interactive theorem proving to a non-math / non-CS audience (the code examples are in Lean 3, though, you’ll want to learn Lean 4, now):
https://pubs.rsc.org/en/content/articlelanding/2024/dd/d3dd00077j
Cool, Tyler. I imagine some of my colleagues will want to read it as well, thanks!
